 hence the payable attribute and value: msg.value object

documentation.text:
@dev call the oracle using OrmrOracle instance, we need to send ETH as subsequent requests to provable are not free
 hence the payable attribute and value: msg.value object

encounterResult(string).details: emits the result of the battle initiated by the user. shows in front-end

callOracleRandom().details: call the oracle using OrmrOracle instance, we need to send ETH as subsequent requests to provable are not free hence the payable attribute and value: msg.value object

convertToUint(bytes).details: Let's do something with our Oracle here. Because we want to display uint to the user and our Oracle returns bytes format, let's convert it here. Web3examples convert to uint https://github.com/web3examples/ethereum/blob/master/solidity_examples/bytes2uint.sol

params.input: the bytes we want to convert to uint

returns._0: the converted bytes value as uint

createHero(string).details: below follows the game logic of creating heroes and dragons, combat and handling Oracle requests

returns._0: return hero associated with the user requesting the address
returns all heroes in array form

getTemp().details: only request AFTER the oracle has been called (and wait atleast 2 blocks for the result + callback) otherwise it will return NULL and undefined. This method also converts the result to uint right away for display in the front-end

returns._0: returns the result of the oracle call as bytes

getTempUint().details: only request AFTER the oracle has been called (and wait atleast 2 blocks for the result + callback) otherwise it will return NULL and undefined. This method also converts the result to uint right away for display in the front-end

returns._0: returns the result of the oracle call as uint

ownerSays().details: function to demonstrate the modifier for PD-9

returns.messageFromOwner: our owner left a message reminding himself he's the boss

startEncounter().details: This is the function our user sees when starting a battle.

HF.details: HF herofactory we use to create heroes     DF dragonfactory we use to create dragonsOO oracle we call for our random functions

startEncounter().notice: here you can initiate a battle! make sure there is both a dragon and hero

userdoc.notice: Calling the Oracle might take a few seconds to minutes, depending on block processing speed.
